description: Simon King explains what's behind the bright orange clouds you may have noticed on Wednesday.
title: Rare red fiery 'udder clouds' spotted in UK skies
title_page: Rare red fiery 'udder clouds' spotted in UK skies - BBC Weather
maintext:
Unusual mammatus clouds were spotted on Wednesday morning in parts of the United Kingdom.
The name mammatus comes from the Latin mamma which means 'udder' or 'breast'.
The bulging cloud was made to look even more dramatic with a fiery, orange glow from the sunrise.
These clouds are often associated with thunderstorm clouds and accompanied by rain, hail and lightning.
Mammatus is most often found at the base of a thunderstorm cloud called cumulonimbus.
With lots of turbulence in the cloud there are lots of up and downdrafts.
The downdrafts can become so severe that air is forced beneath the cloud, creating large bulges of air and water droplets.
If you see mammatus cloud like this, it is a sure sign of impending heavy rain, hail or a big thunderstorm.
Some of the best examples of mammatus can be seen when the sun is low in the sky, casting light on the underside of the cloud and showing up the 'udders'.
Lots of our BBC Weather Watchers particularly in North Yorkshire, managed to capture this cloud on Wednesday morning.
